Q1.competency: Understands the monitoring tools used by the company and how to use them effectively for different purposes (e.g. logs, stats, security).

examples.0: May be aware of monitoring tools but does not actively use them in day-to-day work.
examples.1: Is familiar with core monitoring tools and their purpose, but needs some guidance to use them effectively.
examples.2: Uses monitoring tools proactively. Actively looks for inches, digs into historical data and increases the quality and health of systems based on that data.
examples.3: Evangelize current standards for monitors. Actively seeks to improve current standards and create new standards.

Q2.competency: Understands different metrics of server health, application health, and performance.

examples.0: Has limited familiarity with server health, resource usage, and other metrics of quality.
examples.1: Understands some of the indications of server health and application performance (such as CPU, Memory, Disk, Utilization) and the factors that impact them.
examples.2: Understands what metrics should be optimized and when optimization is less necessary due to diminishing returns. Knows how to respond when those metrics hit certain thresholds.
examples.3: Has deep knowledge of Real time, availability, and health monitoring. Is actively monitoring the most important metrics of server and application health and performance. Takes consistent action to enable a high-performance application to function effectively.

examples.0: Is unaware of team or company standards.
examples.1: Is aware of team and company standards. They can follow them without assistance.
examples.2: Follows company standards and understands the importance of adhering to them.
examples.3: Actively works diligently to adhere to standards and improve them if necessary. Sets an example for others to follow and does the right thing. Promotes company standards to other less experienced team members.

Q4.competency: Plans for current and future capacity.

examples.0: Does not think of future capacity when designing or maintaining their systems.
examples.1: Is aware of their systems current capacity and can forecast future capacity needs with some help.
examples.2: Is aware of current capacity trends for their team's systems. Implements capacity changes before they are an issue.
examples.3: Can help others plan for future capacity and advocates for good capacity planning.

Q5.competency: Identifies, explains, and resolves server issues.

examples.0: Can assist with troubleshooting issues but may have difficulty finding their exact causes and requires supervision from a more experienced team member.
examples.1: Can troubleshoot and fix issues. Can identify an issue and may need guidance from a senior engineer to resolve.
examples.2: Quickly resolves and fixes issues of all types within the team's infrastructure.
examples.3: Efficiently identifies issues in high pressure situations such as outages. Is the go-to person when other engineers cannot isolate and identify issues.

Q6.competency: Designs systems to fail gracefully and handle error conditions (e.g. service failures, logging).

examples.0: Has limited familiarity with how to best handle error conditions.
examples.1: Can design a system that handles errors and exceptions from dependent systems.
examples.2: Can design a robust system that defends against common error scenarios such as bad responses from services and log the appropriate information to allow quick and efficient troubleshooting.
examples.3: Has deep knowledge and understanding of how error handling works in all aspects of the team's infrastructure. Knows how to safely log errors for monitoring. Designs systems in a defensive way to protect against all situations - including rare failures.

T1.competency: Proactively manages alarms and alerts for performance issues.

examples.0: Is not aware on how to troubleshoot performance issues or has limited knowledge on next steps to take.
examples.1: Understands alarms and alerts and takes action to correct issues.
examples.2: Has an in-depth knowledge of alarms and alerts and takes necessary steps to correct. Proactively monitors performance and is able to consistently prevent or minimize performance issues.
examples.3: Helps develop and improve processes and technology to help teams gain efficiency and speed in response of issues.

T2.competency: Knows how to create a baseline for performance of systems.

examples.0: Has little or no knowledge for what items to measure for performance.
examples.1: Is aware of a few basic performance items to monitor (CPU utilization, disk space & memory utilization, availability, response time, etc.).
examples.2: Has a very deep understanding of what tools to use, how to configure the tools, and understands the results of tests for monitored events, and what solution to offer to increase performance/functionality of system.
examples.3: Improve documentation and acts as a mentor to help level up other team members.

T3.competency: Is actively involved with other teams as SME for troubleshooting performance issues.

examples.0: Does not participate in meetings or crisis calls.
examples.1: Is reactive in resolving issues that other involved teams have monitored as issues.
examples.2: Actively participates with other teams to monitor and fix performance degradation. Proactively reaches out to other teams as the SME for resolving performance issues.
examples.3: Understands and shares common architectural patterns that may cause or fix performance issues. Works across teams to propose changes to reduce performance issues.

examples.0: Recognizes when there may be an issue but has a hard time discerning what steps to take to begin troubleshooting.
examples.1: Generally recognizes the type of issue to focus troubleshooting based on symptoms (CPU, Memory, Disk, Network, Hardware, Software).
examples.2: Quickly identifies issues. Knowing the correct tools and processes to effectively and efficiently resolve issues in a timely manner.
examples.3: Can quickly troubleshoot issues and find their solutions. Efficiently identifies issues in high pressure situations such as outages. The go-to person when other engineers cannot isolate and identify issues.

examples.0: Has limited understanding or knowledge of the systems the team owns, therefore does not know the best way to troubleshoot issues that arise.
examples.1: Proficient in troubleshooting the technology of the specific systems a team member owns.
examples.2: Proficient in troubleshooting the technology of the specific systems the team owns.
examples.3: Proficient in troubleshooting a wide range of technologies used across the enterprise.

T6.competency: Integration troubleshooting skills (complex systems interacting with each other)

examples.0: Has limited understanding or knowledge of how systems interact, therefore does not know the best way to troubleshoot issues that arise.
examples.1: Team member is proficient in troubleshooting integration issues between systems they individually own and others.
examples.2: Team member is proficient in troubleshooting integration issues between systems the team owns and others.
examples.3: Team member understands enterprise integration patters and practices. Even with limited exposure or no previous ownership they are proficient in troubleshooting integration issues between systems across the enterprise.

examples.0: Does not know how to test server performance or ignores server performance metrics.
examples.1: Can find server performance metrics and can test server performance with guidance from others.
examples.2: Takes and active and consistent interest to baseline and improve server performance. Can debug performance issues in real time.
examples.3: Consistently identifies potential bottlenecks in the performance of a system. Frequently optimizes infrastructure to be more efficient. Considers performance tuning a key part of a server's lifecycle.

S1.competency: Storage Solutions and Standards (Local LUN Layout/Backups/Network share configuration)

examples.0: Has limited awareness of the Storage Solutions and Standards used. Requires direction on how to properly build/configure a storage solution to support a system's required functionality.
examples.1: Has a basic understanding of a few Storage Solutions and Standards used in our environment. Requires guidance on how to properly build/configure a storage solution to support a system's required functionality. Understands how to do basic troubleshooting for issues relating to the Storage subsystem.
examples.2: Has a foundational understanding and experience with the various Storage Solutions and Standards. Understands how to properly build/configure a storage solution to support a system's required functionality. Understands how to troubleshoot performance issues relating to the Storage subsystem and their effects on the system as a whole.
examples.3: Has an in-depth understanding and experience with the various Storage Solutions and Standards. Can provide detailed guidance regarding building/configuring a proper storage solution for a system to achieve optimal performance and stability. Is able to accurately troubleshoot performance issues relating to the Storage subsystem and their effects on the system as a whole.

examples.0: Schedules and performs routine maintenance on their system only when directed by others. Has basic understanding of what maintenance is required for a system.
examples.1: Routinely schedules and performs routine maintenance on their system with guidance from others. has a basic understanding of what maintenance is required for a system. Will automate some aspects of the systems configuration or ongoing maintenance steps to ensure consistency in the system when directed. Will research ways to improve a system's performance, stability, and/or supportability only to resolve issues.
examples.2: Routinely schedules and performs routine maintenance on their system. Has knowledge of what maintenance is required for a system. Works to automate some aspects of the system's configuration or ongoing maintenance steps to ensure consistency in the system. Seeks out ways to improve a system's performance, stability, and/or supportability in order to resolve issues.
examples.3: Proactively schedules and performs routine maintenance on their system. Has in-depth knowledge of what maintenance is required for a system. Works to automate all aspects of the system's configuration or ongoing maintenance steps to ensures consistency in the system. Proactively seeks out ways to improve a system's performance, stability, and/or supportability.

examples.0: Has basic knowledge of overall network configuration, network segmentation, and security requirements in relation to their system. Can describe at a high level the network layout for their system.
examples.1: Has knowledge of overall network configuration, network segmentation, and security requirements in relation to their system. Has a basic knowledge of firewall/DMZ requirements in relation to their system. Can describe at a high level the network layout for their system.
examples.2: Has foundational knowledge of overall network configuration, network segmentation, and security requirements in relation to their system. Can provide guidance on network layout to provide functionality and redundancy while strictly adhering to our security architecture policies. Has knowledge of firewall/DMZ requirements in relation to their system. Can describe at a high level the network layout and data flow in regards to their system.
examples.3: Demonstrates a strong working knowledge of overall network configuration, network segmentation, and security requirements in relation to their system. Can provide detailed guidance on proper network layout to provide functionality and redundancy while strictly adhering to our security architecture policies. Has a deep knowledge of firewall/DMZ requirements in relation to their system. Can describe in depth the network layout and data flow in regards to their system.

examples.0: Has little understanding of how the application for their system integrates with other applications and services in order to provide functionality. Is able to describe some of the integrations and dependencies for the application.
examples.1: Has a basic understanding of how the application for their system integrates with other applications and services in order to provide functionality. Is able to describe the integrations and dependencies for the application. Can perform basic troubleshooting for the application and identify failures within some of the application's integrations or dependencies.
examples.2: Has a good understanding of how the application for their system integrates with other applications and services in order to provide functionality. Is able to describe in detail, all integrations and dependencies for the application. Can troubleshoot and identify failures within any of the application's integrations or dependencies.
examples.3: Has an in-depth understanding of how the application for their system integrates with other application sand services in order to provide functionality. Is able to describe in detail, all integrations and dependencies for the application. Can accurately troubleshoot and identify failures within any of the application's integrations or dependencies.

S5.competency: Requirements and process for deploying applications

examples.0: Has basic knowledge of a few of the methods available to deploy applications across the enterprise for specific software.
examples.1: Has knowledge of some of the methods available to deploy applications across the enterprise. Has basic scripting knowledge that can be used for deployment.
examples.2: Has an in-depth knowledge of the methods available to deploy applications across the enterprise for a wide range of software. Has scripting experience and knowledge that can be used for deployment and automation. Often works on process improvement for simpler, faster, and more consistent deployments.
examples.3: Has extensive knowledge of methods to deploy applications across the enterprise for a wide range of software. Has extensive scripting experience and knowledge that can be used for deployment and automation. Actively works on process improvement for simpler, faster, and more consistent deployments. An expert in the application deployment process and often consults and assists other teams with troubleshooting and deploying software.

examples.0: Understands some of the best practices for systems in our environment and how they are to be implemented. Has a basic understanding of the overall system architecture, processes, and standards in relation to their systems.
examples.1: Understands the best practices for systems in our environment and how they are to be implemented. Can talk on a high level of the overall system architecture, processes, and standards in relation to their systems.
examples.2: Through the use of system knowledge, helps to decide the best practices for systems in their environment. Can pull from their knowledge and experience to improve their systems. Talks in-depth on the overall system architecture, processes, and standards in relation to their systems. Provides guidance with their systems and the functionality that the provide in the team's environment.
examples.3: Often demonstrates a high level of system knowledge that helps to define best practices for systems across the company. A leading voice on the team that pulls from their knowledge and experience to consistently improve our systems. Talks in-depth concerning our overall system architecture, processes, and standards. Can provide an expert level of guidance with our existing systems and what functionality they provide in our environment.

S7.competency: Understands the implications of changing or updating dependencies

examples.0: Has basic knowledge of the system and some of its dependencies. Has a basic understanding of the impact of changes to the system. Is able to troubleshoot the system and its dependencies.
examples.1: Has knowledge of the system and some of its dependencies. Has an understanding of the impact of changes to the system or any of its dependencies. Is able to troubleshoot the system and its dependencies.
examples.2: Has fundamental knowledge and experience with the system and all its dependencies. Has a basic understanding of the impact of changes to the system or any of its dependencies and how it will affect the environment. Is able to troubleshoot the system and its dependencies. Has a basic knowledge of where the critical points of integration exist between systems and how to identify them if an issue were to occur.
examples.3: Has in-depth knowledge and experience with the system and all its dependencies. Understands the impact of changes to the system or any of its dependencies and how it will affect the environment. Is able to accurately document and troubleshoot the system and its dependencies. Understands where the critical points of integration exist between systems and how to mitigate them if an issue were to occur.

examples.0: Has a basic understanding of collecting baseline performance metrics for a system. Has limited knowledge of the various performance counters used in the baseline performance metrics.
examples.1: Has experience properly collecting and analyzing baseline performance metrics for a system. Has a basic level of knowledge on the various performance counters used in the baseline performance metrics. Can use the metrics to identify potential bottlenecks with a system.
examples.2: Has experience properly collecting and analyzing baseline performance metrics for a system. Has a foundational knowledge on the various performance counters used in the baseline performance metrics and what their effects on the system are. Can use the metrics to identify potential bottlenecks within a system. Has experience of using the baseline metrics to trend usage of the system over time.
examples.3: Has an in-depth knowledge and experience properly collecting and analyzing baseline performance for a system. Has a deep knowledge on the various performance counters used in the baseline performance metrics and what their effects on the system are. Can identify and resolve performance bottlenecks within a system. Has experience and a deep understanding of using the baseline metrics to trend usage of the system over time.

I1.competency: Understands the frameworks/libraries commonly used by the development teams and how they integrate with other infrastructure.

examples.0: Aware of the frameworks used by development teams but has limited experience with them and their integration points.
examples.1: Demonstrates basic understanding and knowledge of the frameworks and their integration points.
examples.2: Able to dig deep into framework integration points and troubleshooting to include Splunk, Core Logger, UM Queues, web.config connection strings, etc.
examples.3: Has great experience with framework integration points used by the team's applications. Works with developers and architects to identify opportunities to serve the QL community with shared code or to solve common problems across development and support teams.

I2.competency: Understands how to properly implement authentication and authorization.

examples.0: May have implemented simple login or authentication but does not have an understanding of best practices.
examples.1: Understands how to integrate a team's applications with company authentication methods such as active directory and Ping Single Sign On for internal team members or Auth for clients.
examples.2: Has experience with implementing both authorization and authentication for a team's application. Understands the security requirements and concerns for gating access to sensitive data and follows best practices from both QL and the industry.
examples.3: Understands implementation details for many authentication protocols such as NTLM, Kerberos, OAuth, OpenID Connect, and SAML. Has familiarity with authorization methods used within the company such as Authorizer, Active Directory, RBAC, or ACL system.

I3.competency: Uses, creates, and contributes to automation via powershell, ansible, bash, cloud formation, etc. scripts.

examples.0: Has not contributed to shared scripts used by others.
examples.1: Has contributed to a script used by multiple projects - including those outside their own team.
examples.2: A primary contributor to several shared repositories such as git or Confluence. Encourages others to move reusable code into separate repositories for greater impact and sharing.
examples.3: Actively maintains large repositories used across the company. Has great knowledge of maintaining automation packages and follows development best practices when making changes - including consistent versioning schemes. Likely involved in the maintenance and administration of internal automation package repositories and assists others with automation script development.

examples.0: Has no cloud experience or is not involved in internal or external knowledge sharing or training.
examples.1: Evangelizes the cloud-first culture.
examples.2: Understands the benefits QL receives from cloud initiatives and the value it brings back to the company. Encourages collaboration through architecture reviews, knowledge-share, and open collaboration on projects.
examples.3: Involved in promoting QL cloud-first efforts - both internally (Platform Delivery) and externally (FOC).

I5.competency: Understand inter-system communication methods (e.g. REST, API Gateway, Queues).

examples.0: May have experience integrating with external systems but has limited understanding of the underlying methods.
examples.1: Has familiarity and experience with common methods used for inter-system communication at QL such as REST, API Gateway, and Queues.
examples.2: Can integrate a service used by other services or systems using best practices and industry-standard protocols. Understands the value of following standards in utilizing public APIs.
examples.3: has an in-depth understanding of communication methods and common enterprise system architecture. Has familiarity with optimizing inter-system communication methods.

I6.competency: Respects how infrastructure changes may affect downstream consumers.

examples.0: Makes changes without fully considering or testing the impact to team members (system, network, configuration, system updates, etc.).
examples.1: Makes documentation such as install guides, configuration details and application and system contacts they own.
examples.2: Understands best practices for inter-system communication and dependencies. Minimizes breaking changes and has respect for team members and consumers for their services and systems.
examples.3: Takes care to present a thoughtful client experience - such as clear communication, responding with a sense of urgency and meeting project deadlines. Has the ability to identify and act upon future state change complications and the ability to drive industry best practices.

I7.competency: Helps design and encourage systems engineering standards (e.g. performance, testing, best practices).

examples.0: Is not involved in defining systems engineering standards or shows no interest.
examples.1: Participates and provides feedback on systems engineering standards (internally or externally).
examples.2: Understands the value of common standards and guides discussions and driving consensus among their team or multiple teams.
examples.3: An expert and thought leader within Technology. Helps teams and entire communities develop standards to improve their deliverable.

examples.0: Has production experience with only one tier.
examples.1: Is familiar with the specific use cases and needs of multiple tiers. Has contributed to implementing systems with multiple tiers.
examples.2: Can make significant contributions that follow company standards and NFRs to systems with multiple tiers.
examples.3: Has architected or built a significant portion of several production-quality systems with multiple tiers.

F2.competency: Knowledgeable of multiple data management systems and when they are most effective.

examples.0: Has heard of relational database management system (RDBMS) but has limited experience with them.
examples.1: Is familiar with RDBMS and has used a SQL back-end for production-quality application - including writing queries.
examples.2: Has great knowledge of at least one database system and used it extensively. Is familiar with other types of database systems. Has experience managing databases such as writing queries and working with DBAs to troubleshoot and resolve issues. Familiar with database strategies and architectures such as T-Log shipping. Asynchronous AG, Synchronous AG and fail-over clustering and which scenarios to use each in. Assist with fail-over and back-up strategies.
examples.3: Has in-depth understanding of many types of databases and their strengths and weaknesses including SQL, Dynamo DB, Mongo DB, etc. Has used multiple types of database back-ends in production systems. Understanding of SQL indexing and its performance impact.

F3.competency: Can design and create a complete infrastructure stack for an application (front-end, mid-ware, database).

examples.0: Can set up the basic technology used by the application stack to the company's standards using core services. Needs guidance from more senior engineers.
examples.1: Can follow documentation and set up system dependencies such as F5s, FW requests, UM Queues, API Gateway, etc. following InfoSec best practices. May need guidance from more senior engineers to help troubleshoot.
examples.2: Can set up all infrastructure and required dependencies for all layers of the applications with minimal or no oversight.
examples.3: Defines procedure and writes documentation for set up of all infrastructure and required dependencies and has in-depth knowledge of system dependencies and how to install them - including any required VMs, databases, or system tools. Actively works on process improvement and knowledge share with others. Mentors others.

F4.competency: Understands underlying operating system features or packages and how to integrate and configure them to support runtime application code.

examples.0: Has experience building out a server to the company's standards.
examples.1: Understands how to install operating system features or packages used by team's application code. Knows how to troubleshoot and read error logs.
examples.2: Knows how to troubleshoot operating system features or packages in supporting run-time application code. Understands integration points between system and application - including dependencies. Can install custom modules or extensions and knows to manage system dependencies through system package managers such as yum, apt-get, chocolatey, etc.
examples.3: Has extensive experience managing system dependencies and requirements for installing and running applications in production configuration. Understands the requirements for integrating with native system's launcher (e.g. win services, system.d, init.d, supervisor, etc.) for creating robust app server setups.

F5.competency: Can make changes to all levels of the application infrastructure (e.g. client-side, front-end, mid-ware, database).

examples.0: Contributes to at least one level of the team's applications and can provide troubleshooting input.
examples.1: Can make changes to several layers of the applications' infrastructure.
examples.2: Can make changes to all layers of the applications infrastructure and actively improves all components of the team's applications systems.
examples.3: Has in-depth understanding of each layer and can dive deep when necessary. Makes recommendations and mentors others to improve performance and resiliency on application infrastructure.

V1.competency: Seeks out opportunities to automate process in order to avoid manual, time-consuming work.

examples.0: Does not know how to script or automate.
examples.1: Knows where to find available internal or external scripts that are compatible with their team's systems and seeks them out before starting large new issues or projects. understands the value of having common shared scripts and not reinventing the wheel by writing unnecessary code.
examples.2: Seeks out new technologies in their system space and how they make their applications better. Implements new technology when a high quality option exists and knows when it is valuable to write their own implementation that meets the needs of QL.
examples.3: Actively encourages an open-source culture and shared common scripts to reduce the need for rewriting code. Helps the internal community come together and increase knowledge share and sharing of code. Has experience with automation and helps guides others looking for automated solutions.

V2.competency: Learns new Technology or systems and teaches team members when appropriate.

examples.0: Has shown limited interest in learning new technology beyond that used by the team.
examples.1: Has learned basics of a new technology or implemented it during a Hack Week project.
examples.2: Demonstrates curiosity and interest in learning new technology and applying it to QL to make themselves and others more efficient or produce higher quality service. Works with architects to investigate new technology or products when introduced into the company or the team's applications.
examples.3: Actively investigates and reviews new technology. Can justify their use and when to make use of them within QL in an enterprise setting. Understands the ramifications of introducing a new technology within QL in a mission critical system. Has discovered, researched, and implemented a new technology within QL while satisfying NFRs and company standards for quality and security.

V3.competency: Is actively involved with IT Communities (e.g. giving talks, helping others)

examples.0: Does not actively participate in IT communities or contribute knowledge.
examples.1: Participates in IT communities and actively involved in developing standards and best practices across teams and applications.
examples.2: Gives talks during Hack Week and IT communities. Actively shares knowledge and improves engineering skills. Mentors other engineers.
examples.3: Leads an IT community. Frequently gives talks both within QL and outside of QL at conferences or meetups. Is a domain expert and makes great effort to be available to assist teams.

V4.competency: Stays current on new and upcoming technologies.

examples.0: Has shown limited interest in learning new technology beyond that used by the team.
examples.1: Learns about new technology in the industry by attending Hack Week experiments, attending conferences, or reading online materials, blogs, and articles.
examples.2: Shows active interest and curiosity in new initiatives and services or systems within QL. Stays up to date on new technology in their domain. Knows about upcoming technology changes used by the team and shares that knowledge with others.
examples.3: has their finger on the pulse of technology and the industry. Actively stays current on all technologies in their domain including front-end, back-end, database, and any other systems used by their team - even components they do not directly contribute to. Usually one of the first in the company to know about an upcoming technology and how it may be useful.

A1.competency: Designs composable systems (modular based on server group type; designed for HA/DR: active/active, active/standby)

examples.0: Needs guidance to avoid adding technical debt or over-engineered components.
examples.1: Interprets architecture diagrams to understand different component groupings.
examples.2: Significant contributor to a composable system to avoid service disruption from vendor and upstream issues. Thinks ahead and considers long-term vision of their applications to minimize technical debt and increase velocity of delivery to stakeholders.
examples.3: Leads system design for one or more large-scale extensible and modular systems. Drives best practices and engagement within their team and clients for building better systems within the enterprise.

A2.competency: Understands how their team's applications integrate with external systems.

examples.0: Has limited understanding of the system topology and architecture diagrams of the team's applications.
examples.1: Understands the dependencies such as services and databases of their team's applications and how they communicate with them.
examples.2: Familiar with the architectural diagrams of their team's applications and what systems they are reliant on - including specific data contracts and specifications in addition to endpoints or services used. Understands service failures or errors and how to handle them gracefully with methods such as back-offs, exponential timeouts and when to surface those error conditions to consumers.
examples.3: Drives application and system design to be more resilient and less coupled to changes to upstream services. Sets best practices for inter-system communication using common protocols and industry standards for performance, security, and interoperability.

A3.competency: Understands system architectural patters and when to use them effectively. Seeks to use the proper combination of hardware and software based on the requirements of the project and the roadmap.

examples.0: May be familiar with common architectural patters but has no hands-on experience with them.
examples.1: Familiar with system architectural patters such as SOA, microservices, monoliths, multi-tenancy, containerization, and more.
examples.2: Understands the benefits and trade-offs of different architectures and has experience using that knowledge to be a significant contributor to the design and implementation of a production system.
examples.3: Has in-depth knowledge on many types of system architecture and most in use within the company. Understands the impact each type of architecture has on operational concerns such as scalability, availability, consistency, backups, monitoring, and logging as well as development concerns such as simplicity, flexibility, ownership, and autonomy.

A4.competency: Understands the flow of data used by their team's systems.

examples.3: Understands data requirements and limitations of data formats, storage, and transport used across the enterprise. Sets standards for protecting data and pushes others to be more respectful and protective of company data.

Often has a technical vision for their projects and plans to address internal software technical debt as well as system or integration issues.

examples.2: Writes technical and non-technical documentation such as system references, project decisions, and architecture. Keeps documentation up-to-date to ensure correctness and clarity.
examples.3: Writes clear, thorough, and useful documentation in every facet of their systems. Designs system architecture. examples.0: Has shown limited interest in diving deep and becoming an expert in specialized technology or business area.
examples.1: Shows and active and consistent curiosity in multiple specific systems relevant to the team. Actively looks for opportunities to be involved in company projects and initiatives in those systems.
examples.2: Actively pursues their interest as a specialist in the majority of systems relevant to their team. Shows consistent progress and growth with their experience and knowledge.

A9.competency: Understands how to create scalable systems.

examples.0: Has no familiarity or experience with building and managing enterprise-sized systems that can scale efficiently.
examples.1: Familiar with metrics and tools used for determining scalability of software. Understands best practices to improve scalability of the systems used by their team. Works across teams to improve handling of availability, backups, monitoring, logging, and documentation.
examples.2: Has in-depth knowledge of design patters to improve scalability such as statelessness, caching, lazy loading, asynchronous processing and uses them in their system designs and implementations.
examples.3: Understands scalability concerns and remedies for all layers of a traditional software stack including applications, services, and databases. Frequently reviews performance and alerts of their systems and improves optimization and efficiency.

A10.competency: Understands how to create and manage distributed systems for stability and reliability.

examples.0: Has no familiarity or experience with creating or managing distributed systems.
examples.1: Has familiarity with distributed computing paradigms and principles such as Service Oriented Architecture, message queues, clustering, shared-nothing, and parallelism vs. concurrency.
examples.2: Has experience with setup, administration, and use of distributed systems such as distributed databases, cluster services, or peer-to-peer applications.
examples.3: has in-depth knowledge and experience with distributed computing architectures and applications. Understands the benefits, trade-offs, and challenges of building distributed systems in real-world scenarios.
